Improve Safety

Kirschenman Enterprises - Edison has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Kirschenman Enterprises - Edison continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Kirschenman Enterprises - Edison's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Kirschenman Enterprises - Edison's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Kirschenman Enterprises - Edison has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Kirschenman Enterprises - Edison has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Kirschenman Enterprises - Edison now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a living document. It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Kirschenman Enterprises - Edison employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Kirschenman Enterprises - Edison will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.

Chlorine Detectors
Kirschenman Enterprises Edison uses handheld chlorine detectors when working on or around the chlorine system. These devices detect the presence of chlorine, and signal an alarm when the level of chlorine rises above a certain level.

The chlorine process at Kirschenman Enterprises Edison consists of vessels which are interconnected, or which are co-located such that a release of chlorine could impact the ability to operate vessels that are not directly connected. As such, the chlorine process at Kirschenman Enterprises Edison is treated as a single process.

1.3.1 General 
We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Chlorine

At Kirschenman Enterprises Edison chlorine gas (Cl2) is used to sanitize process water for washing potatoes. The chlorine, when added to water, yields both chloric (HCl) and hypochlorous (HOCl) acid (see chemical equation below) in aqueous solution.  This combination is effective in killing bacteria, viruses, pathogens and other micro-organisms. Note that the equation below is easily reversible which results in off-gassing of chlorine gas from water that contains high concentrations of the acids.

Cl2 + H2O → HOCl + HCl

The chlorination process begins with the chlorine gas being drawn from the one-ton container by vacuum and injected into the water stream to be treated. After the water is injected with chlorine it is termed chlorinated water. Chlorine levels in the chlorinated water depend on which point in the process that readings are taken but can reach levels as high as 1,000 ppm. In the Tube and Flume the normal chlorine levels should range from 100ppm to 300ppm. In the Pit normal chlorine levels should range from 100ppm to 300ppm. The chlorinated water is also very acidic, with pH levels in the range of 2 to 3.

The highly acidic chlorinated water is then piped to a Buffer Tank in order to raise the pH level to a more neutral state of 6.5 to 7 before being sent to the potato wash area. The 500gal Buffer Tank contains a large amount of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) which acts as the neutralizing agent (buffer) for the chlorinated water. The water coming out of the buffer tank is termed buffered chlorinated water.

1.2.5 Safety Systems

Chlorine

Vacuum Regulator
Several safety features are built into the vacuum regulators used in the chlorination process at Kirschenman Enterprises Edison. The regulator acts as a safety shut-off valve in the event that the vacuum is broken. A pressure relief valve has also been incorporated into the vacuum regulator to prevent pressure from building up in the system.

1.2.2 Facility Location
Kirschenman Enterprises Edison is located at 12836 Edison Highway, Edison, CA 93220. The latitude and longitude of the high pressure receivers is 35.345752, -118.862513. The facility is located approximately 960 feet north of state highway 58 in an industrial area surrounded primarily by agriculture land.

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in an area of minimal flood hazard.

Kirschenman Enterprises Edison is located within the Edison Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed the following faults within close proximity:
Unnamed Ground Breaks of 1952 Earthquake - <150 Years
Unnamed Faults East of Oildale - <1,600,000 Years

The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Kirschenman Enterprises Edison has a 2-5% chance of experiencing potentially minor-damage due to ground shaking in 2018.
